markdownRemark.html:
Introduction

Both Vue.js and React.js are magnificent MVVM libraries. Both are handy for developers who acknowledge the limitations of jQuery and working with the DOM directly. One of the problems such libraries solve is that it‚Äôs hard to build large interactive applications with imperative code. In fact, 2021 was the first year in which the majority of developers chose React.js over jQuery.

From another survey taking a close look at 2021 JavaScript Rising Stars we see that Vue.js is effectively the leader. If you are curious and open-minded like me and you would consider Vue.js as an alternative to React.js, this article is for you.

For brevity I‚Äôll use React and Vue without extensions from now on.

Impressions

I believe that both Vue and React provide excellent ecosystems of supporting tools which facilitate adoption in any team who wants to learn and use these types of front-end technologies.

I like them both now, but I did struggle for in the first few months to be as effecitve in Vue as I were in React. So I decided to write about a few reflections I find worth sharing from my journey.

Tooling

JavaScript tooling is wild. ü§™ It‚Äôs been a never-ending evolution in various aspects.

All popular libraries and frameworks such as React, Vue, Angular, Svelte and others have involving communities of bright and hard-working open-source developers who contribute massively. That‚Äôs why there has been continous evolution in tooling through time regardless of your pick between the popular choices.

In overall, I‚Äôm impressed with the Vue tooling ecosystem.

I start with this topic because it‚Äôs important, althought boring for some. Every production-ready application needs code optimisation and/or transformation. There are numerous open-source and battle-tested solutions on the market and Vue provides integrations for any need and level of expertise.

To start with the easiest, I really like the onboarding experience of the Vue CLI. It‚Äôs well-maintained and has plugins for the most important tasks such as compiling/transpiling, testing with jest, linting with eslint, etc. Comparing it with the CRA I like the Vue CLI‚Äôs DX more.

Another easy option is the Laravel Mix. It‚Äôs an abstraction on top of Webpack which allows users to get started quickly and get their job done without caring too much about toolchain configurations. Deep configurations are possible, of course, through progressive disclosure of Webpack complexity: experienced Webpack configurators can tweak specifics progressively through time without starting from scratch or ejecting.

Laravel Mix plays well with projects bootstrapped with the Vue CLI, as long as babel/eslint/jest configurations are maintained properly. Laravel combined with Laravel Mix is an effective toolchain for PHP developers and that‚Äôs why frequently Vue developers will in PHP (LAMP) stack rather than JavaScript (MEAN-ish) stacks.

For experts, it‚Äôs worth mentioning that Vite has been a trending project in the last couple of months. It‚Äôs not included on the main Vue site and is not as tightly integrated and focused on Vue-only. It is future-proof, keeping up with the non-JavaScript tooling trend for a good reason.

IDE and browser devtools

VS code is not as good at undertanding Vue code as React code out of the box. Autocomplete suggestions and references between code definitions and usage are not always helpful, but it‚Äôs not a big problem.

The extension I recommend is Vetur which covers for almost all necessary features. The only other Vue-related additional extension I use is Sarah Drasner‚Äôs Vue VSCode Snippets.

When it comes to browser integration, all you need to install is Vue Devtools. It‚Äôs great: components‚Äô tree view is clean and without clutter (React‚Äôs case ü´£), there are out-of-the-box integrations for Vuex and Vue Router.

Templates

This section is dedicated to the topic of code writing style and syntax in Vue. These will depend on choices from the bundlers‚Äô section and their configurations. For the following paragraphs I‚Äôll assume the adoption of the most frequently recommended single file component approach.

History

React introduced JSX. It‚Äôs been battle-tested and preferred by many development teams regardless of the initial criticism. JSX is ‚Äújust javascript‚Äù and with this there‚Äôs high focus on component-oriented development and composition. After all, a React component is ‚Äújust a function‚Äù. The JSX style fits better in teams with deeper JavaScript knowledge, on top of jQuery, and the ES6+ features.

Forget about JSX when working with Vue.

When it comes to Vue, web developers with experience in PHP and jQuery appreciate Vue syntax, because Vue templates are more about HTML rather than JavaScript. So, yeah, when you work with developers who are used to make dynamic HTML templates with inline variables, control statements and loops, Vue is more appealing and understandable.

An interesting fact from the history is that Vue‚Äôs default syntax is inspired by Angular 1, not PHP templating. Angular 1 just entered EOL (End of Life phase) but it played a key role in making the MEAN stack a viable alternative to the LAMP stack.

Google Creative Labs was where Evan first started his work on Vue. As the project grew, the team started to use Angular 1. it had too many features that they didn‚Äôt need. Evan also didn‚Äôt like some of the design decisions that Angular 1 had. So, Evan started to work on a templating library just for his personal use. After six months, in February 2014, he officially released it as Vue.js. (source)

Knowing a bit of history is nice, but what are the key concepts to grasp in order smoothen the learning curve when it comes to Vue templates?

Key features and concepts

üîß Attributes [documentation]

Elements in HTML have attributes; these are additional values that configure the elements or adjust their behavior in various ways to meet the criteria the users want. (source)

  • Dynamic attributes are marked with v-bind or simply :. Most frequently used fo class and style attributes.
  • Event handlers are marked with v-on or simply @.
  • is is an attribute used in dynamic components. This feature is quite unique and handy! ü™Ñ
  • use v-model for data binding. Pay attention to emitting input events.

üß© Slots [documentation]

Another unique feature of Vue which resembles (more or less) children prop is in React facilitating components‚Äô inheritance and composition. In the PHP world, this would translate (more or less) to extends and blocks in twig.

Slots are a must-read and must-understand feature which provides code flexibility and reusability.

üîó Refs [documentation]

These are similar to other refs, yes. They should be used carefully because it‚Äôs easy to introduce fishy code through lack of understanding of boundaries between the DOM and Vue.

Refs in Vue return an object of DOM elements and component instances. This means that there is a combination of different APIs methods. There are no limitations with regards to breaking the boundaries I just mentioned, so it could happend that Vue methods are invoked (instead of DOM such) causing unintentional and hard to debug changes in data.

Refs should be used for focus management, not state management.

The last important piece of advice I‚Äôd share for this topic is about how to safely access Vue refs without getting undefined.

Props

When it comes to defining components‚Äô properties and their validations, I sometimes miss the features and possible strictness which React provides.

PropTypes and sometimes TypeScript on top allow for defining shapes and validations in details whereas Vue‚Äôs props validations are less strict.

Important note coming to mind here is that it‚Äôs impossible to use props's values in Vue component file wihout defining the props object property.

State management

The concept of state is not as prominent in Vue as it is in React. For a refresher, React provides setState() function which does exactly what it is named after. Each change in state triggers re-rendering.

Vue provides data() function which returns reactive variables. Reactivity was the highest point in my learning curve so far. Nested objects remain reactive and keep track of changes when passed around with default assignment operations. This is the best and worst feature of Vue in my personal opinion.

Therefore, my first recommendation to anyone experiencing issues with reactivity in nested objects: justjavascript.com. It‚Äôs a great resource for deeply understanding objects in JavaScript. In increased complexity of nested components and data structures in Vue, the knowledge on how to ‚Äúbreak reference‚Äù to avoid unintentional state changes is vital.

And when discussing complexity, here‚Äôs my second recommendation: consider carefully state management in Vue and Vuex. It‚Äôs not adding extra complexity and it‚Äôs also inspired by Flux similarly to Redux.

Vuex is more accessible than Redux though and I‚Äôd start with it in any new greenfield project because it‚Äôs way easier to scale up a Vue project with clearly managed state following battle-tested patterns.

Last notes, recently I came across Pinia, but I haven‚Äôt tried or used it. Vue 3 uses proxies which is a different approach to reactivity compared to Vue 2.

Computed properties

Computed properties are a unique feature of Vue.js. They facilitate caching of reactive variables. I‚Äôve deliberately kept them for the end, because they are an optimisation technique which comes easily after data() and methods concepts are mastered properly.

Ecosystem

Vue provides excellent ecosystem of ready solutions:

  • Vue CLI or Vite
  • Vue Router
  • Vuex for flux-inspired state management
  • Server-side rendering
  • Nuxt or Vue Next as alternatives to Next.js

These are enough to be truly competitive to alternatives such as React and Angular. The tools listed above are tightly integrated and made accessible for easy onboarding and adoption.

Learning resources

Although every single developer has a unique approach in learning new technologies, the Vue Mastery platform is what I‚Äôd recommend as a first step in anyone‚Äôs learning journey.

Solid team of experienced JavaScript professionals with excellent teaching approach similar to CodeSchool. Additional motivational factor, at least for me, is that the platform contributes back to the Vue project financially.

Of course, there are also a few other very useful resources out there:

  • üòé Awesome Vue
  • ü§ì Vue Patterns
  • üìö Vue Style Guide

Conclusions

I hope this article is useful for anyone interested in learning Vue.js from scratch. Previous knowledge of React.js is helpful because I make several comparisons and associations. However, the key points to takeaway would be still the same even if I‚Äôd discard all of the comparison.

Vue.js is a delightful library and its community and ecosystem of supporting tools make it really eaasy to adopt the technology whenever necessary.

frontmatter.description: After using Vue.js for production level applications in 2021, I decided to share my main takeaways from the point of view of someone who already knows React.js.
frontmatter.title: One year of experience with Vue.js
